verse: When Jesus finished ·praying [saying these things], he went with his ·followers [disciples] across the Kidron Valley [a deep wadi or ravine separating Jerusalem on the east from the Mount of Olives]. On the other side there was a garden [or grove; Gethsemane; Matt. 26:36; Mark 14:32], and Jesus and his ·followers [disciples] went into it.
Judas knew where this place was, because Jesus met there often with his ·followers [disciples]. Judas was the one who ·turned against [betrayed] Jesus.
So Judas came there with a group of soldiers [Roman] and some guards [Jewish temple police] from the ·leading [chief] priests and the Pharisees. They were carrying torches, lanterns, and weapons.
Knowing everything that would happen to him, Jesus went out and asked, “Who is it you are looking for?”
They answered him, “Jesus ·from Nazareth [the Nazarene].”
When Jesus said, “·I am he [I am; see 18:5],” they moved back and fell to the ground.
Jesus asked them again, “Who is it you are looking for?”
“I told you that I am he [see 18:5],” Jesus ·said [answered]. “So if you are looking for me, let the others go.”
This happened so that the words Jesus said before would ·come true [be fulfilled]: “I have not lost any of the ones you gave me [6:39; 17:12].”

[Then] Simon Peter, who had a sword, pulled it out and struck the ·servant [slave; bond-servant] of the high priest, cutting off his right ear. (The ·servant’s [slave’s; bond-servant’s] name was Malchus.)

Jesus said to Peter, “Put your sword back [into its sheath]. Shouldn’t I drink the cup the Father gave me?” [The prophets spoke of a cup of judgment; by dying on the cross Jesus drinks it on our behalf; Jer. 25:15–29.]
Then the soldiers [Roman] with their commander and the guards [Jewish temple police] arrested Jesus. They tied him
and led him first to Annas, the father-in-law of Caiaphas, the high priest that year.
Caiaphas was the one who ·told [advised; counseled] the Jews that it would be better if one man died ·for [on behalf of] all the people.

header: Peter Says He Doesn’t Know Jesus(B)

verse: Simon Peter and another one of Jesus’ ·followers [disciples] ·went along after [followed] Jesus. This ·follower [disciple] knew the high priest, so he went with Jesus into the high priest’s courtyard.
But Peter waited outside near the ·door [gate]. The ·follower [disciple] who knew the high priest came back outside, spoke to the ·girl at the door [gatekeeper; doorkeeper], and brought Peter inside.
The ·girl at the door [gatekeeper; doorkeeper] said to Peter, “Aren’t you also one of that man’s ·followers [disciples]?”

It was cold, so the ·servants [slaves; bond-servants] and guards [temple police] had built a [charcoal] fire and were standing around it, warming themselves. Peter also was standing with them, warming himself.
The high priest asked Jesus questions about his ·followers [disciples] and his teaching.

Jesus answered him, “I have spoken ·openly [publicly] to ·everyone [the world]. I have always taught in synagogues and in the Temple, where all the Jews come together. I never said anything in secret.
So why do you question me? Ask the people who heard ·my teaching [what I said to them]. They know what I said.”
When Jesus said this, one of the ·guards [officials; temple police] standing there ·hit [slapped] him. The ·guard [official; temple policeman] said, “Is that the way you answer the high priest?”
Jesus answered him, “If I said something wrong, then ·show [testify to; witness to] what it was. But if what I said is ·true [right], why do you hit me?”
Then Annas sent Jesus, who was still tied, to Caiaphas the high priest.

header: Peter Says Again He Doesn’t Know Jesus(C)

verse: As Simon Peter was standing and warming himself, they said to him, “Aren’t you one of that man’s ·followers [disciples]?”

One of the ·servants [slaves; bond-servants] of the high priest was there. This servant was a relative of the man whose ear Peter had cut off [see 18:10]. The servant said, “Didn’t I see you with him in the ·garden [grove]?”
Again Peter ·said it wasn’t true [denied it]. At once ·a rooster [the cock] crowed.

Early in the morning they [the Jewish leaders] led Jesus from Caiaphas’s house to the ·Roman governor’s palace [or governor’s headquarters; Praetorium]. They would not go inside the ·palace [Praetorium], because they did not want to make themselves ·unclean [according to early Jewish sources a Jew who entered the house of a Gentile would become ritually unclean]; they wanted to eat the Passover meal.
So Pilate [Pontius Pilate, the Roman governor of Judea from ad 26 to 37] went outside to them and asked, “What ·charges [accusation] do you bring against this man?”
They answered, “If he were not a ·criminal [evildoer], we wouldn’t have brought him to you.”
Pilate said to them, “Take him yourselves and judge him by your own law.”
(This happened so that what Jesus said about how he would die [by crucifixion rather than stoning] would ·come true [be fulfilled; see 12:32–33].)
Then Pilate went back inside the ·palace [headquarters; Praetorium] and called Jesus to him and asked, “Are you the king of the Jews?”
Jesus ·said [answered], “Is that your own question, or did others tell you about me?”
Pilate answered, “·I am not one of you [Am I a Jew?]. It was your own ·people [nation] and their ·leading [chief] priests who ·handed you over [or betrayed you] to me. What have you done wrong?”

Jesus answered, “My kingdom ·does not belong to [is not of] this world. If it belonged to this world, my servants would have fought to keep me from being ·given over [betrayed; handed over] to the ·Jewish leaders [Jews]. But my kingdom is from another place.”
Pilate said, “So you are a king!”
Pilate said, “What is truth?” After he said this, he went out to the ·crowd [Jews] again and said to them, “I find ·nothing [no case; no basis for a charge] against this man.
But it is your custom that I ·free [release] one prisoner to you at Passover time. Do you want me to ·free [release] the ‘king of the Jews’?”

They shouted back, “No, not him! Let Barabbas ·go free [be released]!” (Barabbas was a ·robber [bandit; revolutionary; terrorist; the Romans referred to insurrectionists as “robbers” or “criminals”].)
